internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The “divide and average” method, an old-time method for approximating the square root of any positive number a, can be formulated as follows:

 

%media:formula1.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop a well-structured function to implement the given algorithm based on the algorithm of the Maclaurin series expansion for ex given below.

 

function [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% Maclaurin series of exponential function
% [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% input:
% x = value at which series evaluated
% es = stopping criterion (default = 0.0001)
% maxit = maximum iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% fx = estimated value
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations
% defaults:
if nargin<2|isempty(es),es=0.0001;end
if nargin<3|isempty(maxit),maxit=50;end
% initialization
iter = 1; sol = 1; ea = 100;
% iterative calculation
while (1)
    solold = sol;
    sol = sol + x ^ iter / factorial(iter);
    iter = iter + 1;
    if sol~=0
        ea=abs((sol - solold)/sol)*100;
    end
    if ea<=es | iter>=maxit,break,end
end
fx = sol;
end

 

(Please upload your response or solutions using the control below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The estimated value is [a(3)].

The Approximate relative error is [a(4)]e[a(5)].

The number of iteration is [a(6)].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB code for the divide and average method for evaluating square roots.

worksheet.stem:
Use the well-structured function developed for the given algorithm to calculate the estimated value, the approximate relative error(%), and the number of iteration for the following data:

Value for which square root is to be computed: [a(1)]

Stopping criterion: [a(2)]

(Round the estimated value and the approximate relative error to four decimal places and the number of iterations to the nearest whole number.) 

 

The estimated value = __1__.

The approximate relative error =  __2__e__4__. 

The number of iteration = __3__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The function can be developed as follows:

 

function [fx,ea,iter] = SquareRoot(a,es,maxit)
% Divide and average method for evaluating square roots
% [fx,ea,iter] = SquareRoot(a,es,maxit)
% input:
% a = value for which square root is to be computed
% es = stopping criterion (default = 0.0001)
% maxit = maximum iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% fx = estimated value
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations
% defaults:
if nargin<2|isempty(es),es=0.0001;end
if nargin<3|isempty(maxit),maxit=50;end
if a<= 0,error('value must be positive'),end
% initialization
iter = 1; sol = a/2; ea = 100;
% iterative calculation
while (1)
  solold = sol;
  sol = (sol + a/sol)/2;
  iter = iter + 1;
  if sol~=0
    ea=abs((sol - solold)/sol)*100;
  end
  if ea<=es | iter>=maxit,break,end
end
fx = sol;
end

 

Output:

>> [fx,ea,iter] = SquareRoot([a(1)],[a(2)])
fx =
     [a(3)]
ea =
   [a(4)]e[a(5)]
iter =
     [a(6)]

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The converted values are given below:

a. ([a(1)])8 = ([a(12)])10

b. ([b(1)])8 = ([b(8)])10

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the method of converting an octal number to a decimal number.

worksheet.stem:
Convert the following base-8 numbers to base 10:

 

a. ([a(1)])8 = (__1__)10 (Round the final answer to the nearest whole number.)

b. ([b(1)])8 = (__2__)10 (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The conversion from base-8 to base 10 is done as follows:

([a(1)])8 = ([a(2)] × 84) +  ([a(3)] × 83) +  ([a(4)] × 82) +  ([a(5)] × 81) +  ([a(6)] × 80) = ([a(12)])10

 

([b(1)])8 = ([b(2)] × 80) +  ([b(3)] × 8–1) +  ([b(4)] × 8–2) = ([b(8)])10

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
For computers, the machine epsilon ε can also be thought of as the smallest number that when added to one gives a number greater than 1. An algorithm based on this idea can be developed as follows:


Step 1: Set ε = 1.

Step 2: If 1 + ε is less than or equal to 1, then go to Step 5.

            Otherwise go to Step 3.

Step 3: ε = ε/2

Step 4: Return to Step 2

Step 5: ε = 2 × ε

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file based on the given algorithm to determine the machine epsilon.

 

(Please upload your response or solutions using the control below.)

function ep = macheps
% determines the machine epsilon
e = 1;
while (1)
   if e+1<=1, break, end
   e = e/2;
end
ep = 2*e;
 

>> macheps

ans =
2.2204e–016


>> eps

ans =

2.2204e–016

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file to determine the smallest positive real number used in MATLAB. Base your algorithm on the notion that your computer will be unable to reliably distinguish between zero and a quantity that is smaller than this number.

 

(Please upload your response or solutions using the control below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The value obtained with the M-file function is –1074.

The value obtained using the built-in function realmin is –1022.

Hence, the result of the M-file actually gives a smaller value than the value obtained from the built-in function realmin.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB program for the smallest positive real number.

worksheet.stem:
Use the M-file of the smallest positive real number used in MATLAB to investigate the results by taking the base-2 logarithm of the number generated by the M-file code and those obtained with realmin. (Round the final answers to the nearest whole numbers.)

 

The value obtained with the M-file function is __1__.

The value obtained using the built-in function realmin is __2__.

Hence, the result of M-file actually gives a __3__ value than the value obtained from the built-in function realmin.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The MATLAB program for the smallest positive real number is 

 

function s = small
% determines the smallest number
sm = 1;
while (1)
  s=sm/2;
  if s==0,break,end
  sm = s;
end
s = sm;

 

This function can be run to give 

 

>> s=small
s =
4.9407e–324

 

This result differs from the one obtained with the built-in realmin function.

 

>> s=realmin
s =
2.2251e–308

 

Challenge question: We can take the base–2 logarithm of both results.

 

>> log2(small)
ans =
–1074

 

>> log2(realmin)
ans =
–1022

 

Thus, the result of our function is 2–1074 (≅ 4.9407×10–324), whereas realmin gives 2–1022 (≅2.2251×10–308). Therefore, the function actually gives a smaller value that is equivalent to

small = 2–52×realmin

 

​Recall that machine epsilon is equal to 2–52. Therefore,

small = eps×realmin

 

​Such numbers, which are called denormal or subnormal, arise because the math coprocessor employs a different strategy for representing the significand and the exponent.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The smallest positive integer value is 1.1755 × 10–38.

The largest positive integer value is 3.4028 × 1038.

The machine epsilon in single precision is 1.1921 × 10–7.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How is the positive number represented in binary form?

hint.name: hint #2
hint.value: How is the negative number represented in binary form?

worksheet.stem:
Although it is not commonly used, MATLAB allows numbers to be expressed in single precision. Each value is stored in 4 bytes with 1 bit for the sign, 23 bits for the mantissa, and 8 bits for the signed exponent. Determine the smallest and largest positive floating-point numbers as well as the machine epsilon for single precision representation. Note that the exponents range from −126 to 127. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The smallest positive integer value is __1__ × 10–38.

The largest positive integer value is __2__ × 1038.

The machine epsilon in single precision is __3__ × 10–7.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Because the exponent ranges from –126 to 127, the smallest positive number can be represented in binary as follows:


smallest value = +1.0000....0000⋅2–126

where the 23 bits in the mantissa are all 0. This value can be translated into a base–10 value of 2–126 = 1.1755 × 10–38. The largest positive number can be represented in binary as

largest value = +1.1111...1111⋅ 2+127

where the 23 bits in the mantissa are all 1. Since the significand is approximately 2 (it is actually 2 – 2–23), the largest value is therefore 2+128 = 3.4028 × 1038.

The machine epsilon in single precision would be 2–23 = 1.1921 × 10–7.


These results can be verified using built-in MATLAB functions.

>> realmax('single')
ans =
3.4028e+038

>> realmin('single')
ans =
1.1755e–038

>> eps('single')
ans =
1.1921e–007

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
For computers that use truncation, the machine epsilon is the positive distance from %media:formula2.mml% to the next larger in magnitude floating-point number of the same precision as x.

1.1 × 100 – 1.0 × 100 = 1.0 × 10–1

For computers that hold intermediate results in a larger-sized word before returning a rounded result, the machine epsilon would be 0.05.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: This is true. For a hypothetical base-10 computer, the machine epsilon is 0.05.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What would be the machine epsilon for computers that hold intermediate results in a larger-sized word before returning a rounded result?

trueFalse.stem: Suppose that we had a hypothetical base-10 computer with a 5-digit word size. Assume that one digit is used for the sign, two for the exponent, and two for the mantissa. For simplicity, assume that one of the exponent digits is used for its sign, leaving a single digit for its magnitude. Then, for these type of hypothetical base-10 computers, the machine epsilon would be 0.05.
trueFalse.commonFeedback:
For computers that use truncation, the machine epsilon is the positive distance from %media:formula2.mml% to the next larger in magnitude floating-point number of the same precision as x.

1.1 × 100 – 1.0 × 100 = 1.0 × 10–1

For computers that hold intermediate results in a larger-sized word before returning a rounded result, the machine epsilon would be 0.05.

trueInfo.feedback:
For computers that use truncation, the machine epsilon is the positive distance from %media:formula2.mml% to the next larger in magnitude floating-point number of the same precision as x.

1.1 × 100 – 1.0 × 100 = 1.0 × 10–1

For computers that hold intermediate results in a larger-sized word before returning a rounded result, the machine epsilon would be 0.05.

falseInfo.feedback:
For computers that use truncation, the machine epsilon is the positive distance from %media:formula2.mml% to the next larger in magnitude floating-point number of the same precision as x.

1.1 × 100 – 1.0 × 100 = 1.0 × 10–1

For computers that hold intermediate results in a larger-sized word before returning a rounded result, the machine epsilon would be 0.05.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The values are listed below:

The value calculated using three-digit chopping is 216,250.

The value calculated using four-digit chopping is 2,048,521.

Using more significant digits improves the estimates.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Compute the true value of the given function for the first derivative.

worksheet.stem:
The derivative of  %media:formula3.mml% is given by  %media:formula4.mml%.

 

Evaluate the given function at x = 0.577 using 3-digit and 4-digit arithmetic with chopping.(Round the final answers to the nearest whole numbers.)

 

The values are listed below:

The value calculated using 3-digit chopping is __1__.

The value calculated using 4-digit chopping is __2__.

Using more significant digits improves the estimates. __3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The true value can be computed as follows:

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

Using three-digits with chopping

 

%media:formula6.mml%

 

x = 0.577

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

3x2 = 0.996

 

1 – 3x2 = 0.004

 

%media:formula8.mml% 

 

This represents a percent relative error of

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

Using four-digits with chopping

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

x = 0.577

 

%media:formula11.mml%

 

3x2 = 0.9987

 

1 – 3x2 = 0.0013

 

%media:formula13.mml%

 

This represents a percent relative error of

 

%media:formula12.mml%

 

Although using more significant digits improves the estimate, the error is still considerable. The problem stems primarily from the fact that we are subtracting two nearly equal numbers in the denominator. Such subtractive cancellation is worsened by the fact that the denominator is squared.

worksheet.stem:

The value is __1__. (Round the final answer to two decimal places.)

The percentage relative error is __2__%. (Round the final answer to one decimal place.)
worksheet.commonFeedback:
First, the correct result can be calculated as follows:

 

y = [a(1)]3 – 7([a(1)])2 + 8([a(1)]) – 0.35 =  [a(2)]

 

Using 3-digits chopping,

 

[a(1)]3 → [a(3)] → [a(4)]

 

–7([a(1)])2 → –[a(7)] → –[a(8)]

 

8([a(1)]) → [a(9)] → [a(10)] 

                           

                           –0.35

                            _____

                            [a(11)]

 

This represents an error of 

 

%media:formula21.mml%

property.name: scoring
property.value: partial credit scoring

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The Taylor series expansion is 

 

%media:formula24.mml%

 

For this case, xi = 0 and h = x. Thus, the Taylor series is

 

%media:formula25.mml%

 

For the exponential function,

 

f(0) = f'(0) = f''(0) = f(3)(0) = 1

 

Substituting these values to yields,

 

%media:formula46.mml%


which is the Maclaurin series expansion.

hint.value: Recall the Taylor series expansion.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the Taylor series expansion for the third-order term?

worksheet.stem:
Use the Taylor series to estimate f(x) = e–x at xi + 1 = 1 for xi = [a(1)]. Employ the zero-order, first-order, second-order, and third-order versions and compute the %media:formula54.mml% for each case. (Round the estimated values to five decimal places and the error values to one decimal place.)

 

The calculated values are as follows:

 

Order Value Error %
Zero __1__ __5__
First __2__ __6__
Second __3__ __7__
Third __4__ __8__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The true value is e–1 = 0.367879 and step size is h = xi + 1 – xi = 1 – [a(1)] = [a(3)]. The complete Taylor series to the third-order term is 

 

%media:formula47.mml%

 

Zero-order approximation

 

f(1) = e–[a(1)] = [a(4)]

 

%media:formula48.mml%

 

First-order approximation

 

f(1) = [a(4)] – [a(4)]([a(3)]) = [a(6)]

 

%media:formula49.mml%

 

Second-order approximation

 

%media:formula51.mml%

 

%media:formula50.mml%

 

Third-order approximation

 

%media:formula52.mml%

 

%media:formula53.mml%

worksheet.commonFeedback:
The true value is f(3) = 554.

Zero-order

 

%media:formula55.mml%

 

%media:formula56.mml%

 

First-order

 

%media:formula57.mml%

%media:formula61.mml%

 

Because we are working with a third-order polynomial, the error is zero. This is due to the fact that cubics have zero fourth and higher derivatives.

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
Here are the function and its derivatives of the given function:

 

%media:formula139.mml%

 

%media:formula140.mml%

 

%media:formula141.mml%

 

%media:formula142.mml%

 

%media:formula143.mml%

 

Using the Taylor series expansion, we obtain the following first-, second-, third-, and fourth-order Taylor series functions shown below in the MATLAB program–f1, f2, and f4. Note the second- and third-order Taylor series functions are the same.

From the plots below, the answer is the fourth-order Taylor series expansion.

 

x=0:0.001:3.2;
f=x-1-0.5*sin(x);
subplot(2,2,1);
plot(x,f);grid;title('f(x)=x-1-0.5*sin(x)');hold on

 

f1=x-1.5;
e1=abs(f-f1); %Calculates the absolute value of the difference/error
subplot(2,2,2);
plot(x,e1);grid;title('1st Order Taylor Series Error');

 

f2=x-1.5+0.25.*((x-0.5*pi).^2);
e2=abs(f-f2);
subplot(2,2,3);
plot(x,e2);grid;title('2nd/3rd Order Taylor Series Error');

 

f4=x-1.5+0.25.*((x-0.5*pi).^2)-(1/48)*((x-0.5*pi).^4);
e4=abs(f4-f);
subplot(2,2,4);
plot(x,e4);grid;title('4th Order Taylor Series Error');hold off

 

%media:4_19.png%

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The fourth-order Taylor series expansion results in a maximum error of 0.015 on the specified interval.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Solve graphically.

multipleChoice.stem:
To calculate a planet’s space coordinates, we have to solve the function

 

%media:formula138.mml%

 

Let the base point be

 

 %media:formula144.mml% 

 

on the interval [0, %media:formula145.mml%]. Determine the highest-order Taylor series expansion resulting in a maximum error of 0.015 on the specified interval. The error is equal to the absolute value of the difference between the given function and the specific Taylor series expansion.
multipleChoice.commonFeedback:
Here are the function and its derivatives of the given function:

 

%media:formula139.mml%

 

%media:formula140.mml%

 

%media:formula141.mml%

 

%media:formula142.mml%

 

%media:formula143.mml%

 

Using the Taylor series expansion, we obtain the following first-, second-, third-, and fourth-order Taylor series functions shown below in the MATLAB program–f1, f2, and f4. Note the second- and third-order Taylor series functions are the same.

From the plots below, the answer is the fourth-order Taylor series expansion.

 

x=0:0.001:3.2;
f=x-1-0.5*sin(x);
subplot(2,2,1);
plot(x,f);grid;title('f(x)=x-1-0.5*sin(x)');hold on

 

f1=x-1.5;
e1=abs(f-f1); %Calculates the absolute value of the difference/error
subplot(2,2,2);
plot(x,e1);grid;title('1st Order Taylor Series Error');

 

f2=x-1.5+0.25.*((x-0.5*pi).^2);
e2=abs(f-f2);
subplot(2,2,3);
plot(x,e2);grid;title('2nd/3rd Order Taylor Series Error');

 

f4=x-1.5+0.25.*((x-0.5*pi).^2)-(1/48)*((x-0.5*pi).^4);
e4=abs(f4-f);
subplot(2,2,4);
plot(x,e4);grid;title('4th Order Taylor Series Error');hold off

 

%media:4_19.png%

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:

Step size Finite difference
0.1 –0.49917
0.01 –0.49999

0.0000000010 –0.50000

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB code for centered difference approximation.

worksheet.stem:
Use a centered difference approximation of O(h2) to estimate the first derivative of f(x) = cos(x) at %media:formula146.mml% with the step size of h = 1. Then progressively divide the step size by a factor of 10 to demonstrate how roundoff becomes dominant as the step size is reduced. (Round the final answers to five decimal places.)

 

Step size Finite difference
0.1 __1__
0.01 __2__
0.000001 __3__
0.0000000010 __4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
We can develop the following M-file to perform the computations and plot the results. Notice that we pass both the function and its analytical derivative as arguments:

 

function diffex(func,dfunc,x,n)
format long
dftrue=dfunc(x);
h=1;
H(1)=h;
D(1)=(func(x+h)-func(x-h))/(2*h);
E(1)=abs(dftrue-D(1));
for i=2:n
h=h/10;
H(i)=h;
D(i)=(func(x+h)-func(x-h))/(2*h);
E(i)=abs(dftrue-D(i));
end
L=[H' D' E']';
fprintf(' step size finite difference true error\n');
fprintf('%14.10f %16.5f %16.13f\n',L);
loglog(H,E),xlabel('Step Size'),ylabel('Error')
title('Plot of Error Versus Step Size')
format short

 

The M-file can then be run using the following commands:

 

>> ff=@(x) cos(x);
>> df=@(x) -sin(x);
>> diffex(ff,df,pi/6,11)


  step size     finite difference   true error
  1.0000000000  -0.42074            0.0792645075961
  0.1000000000  -0.49917                        0.0008329167659
  0.0100000000  -0.49999                        0.0000083332917
  0.0010000000  -0.50000                        0.0000000833333
  0.0001000000  -0.50000                        0.0000000008333
  0.0000100000  -0.50000                        0.0000000000134
  0.0000010000  -0.50000                        0.0000000000144
  0.0000001000  -0.50000                        0.0000000002632
  0.0000000100  -0.50000                        0.0000000025124
  0.0000000010  -0.50000                        0.0000000141410
  0.0000000001  -0.50000                        0.0000000413702

 

The result is plotted as follows:

 

%media:4_22plot.png%

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB code for forward difference approximation.

worksheet.stem:
Use a forward difference approximation of O(h2) to estimate the first derivative of f(x) = –0.1x4 – 0.15x3 – 0.5x2 – 0.25x + 1.2 at x = 0.5 with the step size of h = 1. Then progressively divide the step size by a factor of 10 to demonstrate how roundoff becomes dominant as the step size is reduced. (Round the final answers to five decimal places.)

 

The calculated values are tabulated below:

 

Step size Finite difference
0.1 __1__
0.01 __2__
0.000001 __3__
0.0000000010 __4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
We can develop the following M-file to perform the computations and plot the results. Notice that we pass both the function and its analytical derivative as arguments:

function prob0423(func,dfunc,x,n)
format long
dftrue=dfunc(x);
h=1;
H(1)=h;
D(1)=(func(x+h)-func(x))/h;
E(1)=abs(dftrue-D(1));
for i=2:n
h=h/10;
H(i)=h;
D(i)=(func(x+h)-func(x))/h;
E(i)=abs(dftrue-D(i));
end
L=[H' D' E']';
fprintf(' step size finite difference true error\n');
fprintf('%14.10f %16.5f %16.13f\n',L);
loglog(H,E),xlabel('Step Size'),ylabel('Error')
title('Plot of Error Versus Step Size')
format short

 

The M-file can then be run using the following commands:

 

>> ff=@(x) -0.1*x^4-0.15*x^3-0.5*x^2-0.25*x+1.2;
df=@(x) -0.4*x^3-0.45*x^2-x-0.25;
prob0423(ff,df,0.5,11)
 step size     finite difference true error
  1.0000000000  -2.23750         1.3250000000000
  0.1000000000     -1.00360                  0.0911000000000
  0.0100000000     -0.92129                  0.0087851000000
  0.0010000000     -0.91338         0.0008753500999
  0.0001000000     -0.91259         0.0000875034999
  0.0000100000     -0.91251         0.0000087500284
  0.0000010000     -0.91250         0.0000008749722
  0.0000001000     -0.91250         0.0000000866028
  0.0000000100     -0.91250         0.0000000088872
  0.0000000010     -0.91250         0.0000000355217
  0.0000000001     -0.91250         0.0000000755006

 

The graph for the values is plotted below:

 

%media:4_23plot.png%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
Using the standard quadratic formula, the values of x1 and x2 are as follows:

x1 i= 4,999.9

x2 = 0.05

 

Using equation (2), the values of x1 and x2 are as follows:

x1 = 200

x2 = 0.002

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How are the exact values evaluated using the standard formula with double-precision arithmetic?

worksheet.stem:
One common instance where subtractive cancellation occurs involves finding the roots of a parabola, ax2 + bx + c, with the standard quadratic formula:

 

%media:formula101.mml%     _____(1)

 

For cases where b2 >> 4ac, the difference in the numerator can be very small and roundoff errors can occur. In such cases, an alternative formulation can be used to minimize subtractive cancellation:

 

%media:formula102.mml%     _____(2)

 

Use 5-digit arithmetic with chopping to determine the roots of the following equation with both versions of the quadratic formula. 

 

x2 – 5000.002x + 10

 

Using the standard quadratic formula, the values of x1 and x2 are as follows: (Enter the value of x1 to one decimal place and round the value of x2 to two decimal places.)

x1 = __1__

x2 = __2__

 

Using equation (2), the values of x1 and x2 are as follows: (Round the value of x1 to the nearest whole number and round the value of x2 to three decimal places.)

x1 = __3__

x2 = __4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
First, evaluate the exact values using the standard formula with double-precision arithmetic as follows:


%media:formula103.mml%

 

Then, the square root term with 5-digit arithmetic and chopping is determined as follows:

 

%media:formula104.mml%

 

Standard quadratic formula

 

%media:formula105.mml%

 

%media:formula106.mml%

 

Thus, although the first root is reasonably close to the true value (εt = 0.002%), the second is considerably off (εt = 2400%) primarily due to subtractive cancellation.

Using equation (2),

 

%media:formula107.mml%

 

%media:formula108.mml%

 

For this case, the second root is well approximated, whereas the first is considerably off ( εt = 96%). Again, the culprit is the subtraction of two nearly equal numbers.
